column1: Ramallah was incorporated into the Ottoman Empire in 1517 with all of Palestine. In 1596 it was listed in the tax registers as being in the nahiya of Quds
column2: part of the Liwa of Quds. It had a population of 71 Christian households and 9 Muslim households. It paid a fixed tax rate of 25% on wheat
column3: barley
column4: olives
column5: vines or fruit trees
column6: and goats or beehives; a total of 9
column7: 400 akçe. All of the revenue went to a waqf.Modern Ramallah was founded in the mid-1500s by the Haddadins (also: Haddadeen)
column8: a clan of brothers descended from Ghassanid Christians. The Haddadins (ancestors of the present-day Jadallah family
column11: arrived from east of the Jordan River from the areas of Karak and Shoubak. The Haddadin migration is attributed to fighting and unrest among clans in that area.

column1: Ramallah grew dramatically throughout the 17th and 18th centuries as an agricultural village
column2: attracting more (predominantly Christian) inhabitants from all around the region. In 1700
column3: Yacoub Elias was the first Ramallah native to be ordained by the Eastern Greek Melkite Orthodox Church of Jerusalem
column4: the Christian denomination that prevailed in the Holy Land at the time. In the early 19th century
column5: the first Greek Melkite Jerusalemite Orthodox Christian church was built. Later in the 1850s
column6: "The Church of Transfiguration"
column7: was built to replace it; it is the sole Orthodox Church in Ramallah today. During that same decade
column8: the Latin (Roman Catholic) Church established its presence in Ramallah
column9: constituting the second largest Christian denomination in the city. The Roman Catholic Church established the St. Joseph's Girls' School run by St. Joseph sisters
column10: as well as the co-educational Al-Ahliyyah College high school runs by Rosary sisters. With the influx of Muslim and Christian refugees and internal migration
column11: new mosques and churches were built.In the 19th century
column12: the Religious Society of Friends (Quakers) established a presence in Ramallah and built the Ramallah Friends Schools
column13: one for girls and later a boys' school
column14: to alleviate the dearth of education for women and girls. Eli and Sybil Jones opened "The Girls Training Home of Ramallah" in 1869. A medical clinic was established in 1883
column15: with Dr. George Hassenauer serving as the first doctor in Ramallah. In 1889
column16: the girls academy became the Friends Girls School (FGS). As the FGS was also a boarding school
column17: it attracted a number of girls from surrounding communities
column21: and Beirut. The Friends Boys School (FBS) was founded in 1901 and opened in 1918. The Quakers opened a Friends Meeting House for worship in the city center in 1910. According to the school's official website
column22: most high school students choose to take the International Baccalaureate exams (IBE) instead of the traditional "Tawjihi" university exams.The activity of foreign churches in Palestine in the late 19th century increased awareness of prosperity in the West. In Ramallah and Bethlehem
column24: local residents began to seek economic opportunity overseas. In 1901
column25: merchants from Ramallah emigrated to the United States and established import-export businesses
column26: selling handmade rugs and other exotic wares across the Atlantic. Increased trade dramatically improved living standards for Ramallah's inhabitants. American cars
column29: and later televisions became attainable luxuries for upper-class families. As residents of Jaffa and Lydda moved to Ramallah
column30: the balance of Muslims and Christians began to change.Ramallah was declared a modern city in 1908. It had an elected municipality as well as partnership projects with the adjacent town of al-Bireh. The Friends Boys School became a temporary hospital during World War I.

column1: The British Army occupied Ramallah in December 1917 until the designation of the Palestine mandate in 1920
column2: remaining under British rule until 1948. The economy improved in the 1920s
column3: and the landed aristocracy and merchants of the Palestinian upper class built stately multi-storied villas
column4: many of which still stand. The Jerusalem Electric Company brought electricity to Ramallah in 1936
column5: and most homes were wired shortly thereafter. The same year the British inaugurated the "Palestine Broadcasting Service" in Ramallah. The British Broadcasting Corporation trained the local staff to deliver daily broadcasts in Arabic
column6: Hebrew
column7: and English. The station was later renamed "Kol Yerushalayim" (The Voice of Jerusalem).During the 1936–39 Arab revolt in Palestine
column8: Ramallah was a center of activities against the British. Nancy Parker McDowell describes vividly how the British attacked Ramallah using the Air Force. Many residents were killed and wounded. The wounded had to be transferred to Jerusalem since no significant medical facilities existed in Ramallah.

column1: Following the creation of the State of Israel and the ensuing war
column2: Jordan seized the part of Palestine they named the West Bank. This included Ramallah. The West Bank was relatively peaceful during the years of Jordanian rule between 1948 and 1967
column3: with its residents enjoying freedom of movement between the West Bank
column4: Jordan
column5: Lebanon
column6: and Syria. Jordan annexed the West Bank
column7: applying its national law to the conquered territory. However
column8: many Palestinians were jailed for being members of "illegal political parties"
column9: which included the Palestine Communist Party and other socialist and pro-independence groups. By 1953
column11: but the economy and infrastructure could not accommodate the influx of poor villagers. Natives of Ramallah began to emigrate
column12: primarily to the United States. By 1956
column15: with Arabs from the surrounding towns and villages (particularly Hebron) buying the homes and land the émigrés left behind.

column2: Israel captured Ramallah from Jordan
column3: imposing a military closure and conducting a census a few weeks later. Every person registered in the census was given an Israeli identity card which allowed the bearer to continue to reside there. Those who were abroad during the census lost their residency rights. For residents of Ramallah
column4: the situation had now been reversed. For the first time in 19 years
column5: residents could freely visit Israel and the Gaza Strip and engage in commerce there.

column2: Israel did not offer citizenship to the residents. Ramallah residents were issued permits to work in Israel
column3: but did not gain the rights associated with Israeli citizenship. The city remained under Israeli military rule for more than four decades.

column1: Ramallah residents were among the early joiners of the First Intifada. The Intifada Unified Leadership
column2: an umbrella organization of various Palestinian factions
column3: distributed weekly bulletins on the streets of Ramallah with a schedule of the daily protests
column4: strikes and action against Israeli patrols in the city. At the demonstrations
column5: tires were burned in the street
column6: and the crowds threw stones and Molotov cocktails. The IDF responded with tear gas and rubber bullets. Schools in Ramallah were forcibly shut down
column7: and opened gradually for a few hours a day. The Israelis conducted house arrests
column8: imposing curfews that restricted travel and exports in what Palestinians regarded as collective punishment. In response to the closure of schools
column9: residents organized home schooling sessions to help students make up missed material; this became one of the few symbols of civil disobedience. The Intifada leadership organized "tree plantings" and resorted to the tactics used in pre-1948 Palestine
column10: such as ordering general strikes in which no commercial businesses were allowed to open and no cars were allowed on the streets.In 1991
column11: the Palestinian delegation to the Madrid International Peace Conference included many notables from Ramallah. As the Intifada wound down and the peace process moved forward
column12: normal life in Ramallah resumed. On September 13
column13: 1993 Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin and Palestinian Leader Yasser Arafat shook hands at a meeting at the White House. Schoolchildren in Ramallah handed out olive branches to Israeli soldiers patrolling the streets. In December 1995
column14: in keeping with the Oslo Accords
column15: the Israeli army abandoned the Mukataa and withdrew to the city outskirts. The newly established Palestinian Authority assumed civilian and security responsibility for the city
column16: which was designated "Area A" under the accords.

column1: The years between 1993 and 2000 (known locally as the "Oslo Years") brought relative prosperity to Ramallah. Ramallah and its immediate environs were classified as Area A in the Oslo Accords
column2: under full civil and security control of the Palestinian Authority (PA) administration in September 1995. Many expatriates returned to establish businesses there
column3: and the atmosphere was one of optimism. In 2000
column4: unemployment began to rise and the economy of Ramallah declined. The Israel Defense Forces remained in control of the territories and its government did not restore the freedom of movement enjoyed by Ramallah residents prior to the first Intifada. Travel to Jerusalem required special permits. The number and size of Israeli settlements around Ramallah increased dramatically. A network of bypass roads for use of Israeli citizens only was built around Ramallah
column5: and Israel expropriated land for settlements.Many official documents previously handled by the Israeli Civil Administration were now handled by the Palestinian Authority but still required Israeli approval. A Palestinian passport issued to Ramallah residents was not valid unless the serial number was registered with the Israeli authorities
column6: who controlled border crossings. The failure of the Camp David summit in July 2000 led to the outbreak of the Second Intifada (al-Aqsa Intifada) in September 2000.

column1: Young Ramallah residents demonstrated daily against the Israeli army
column2: with marches to the Israeli checkpoints at the outskirts of the city. Over time
column3: the marches were replaced by sporadic use of live ammunition against Israeli soldiers; and various attacks targeting Jewish settlers
column4: particularly on the Israeli-only bypass roads. Army checkpoints were established to restrict movement in and out of Ramallah.On October 12

column1: This area enjoys a Mediterranean climate of a dry summer and mild
column2: rainy winter with occasional snowfall. The recorded average of Ramallah's rainfall is about 615 mm (24 in) and minimum rainfall is 307 mm (12 in) and maximum rainfall is 1

column1: The Köppen climate classification places Ramallah in the Csa category. Climates of this class generally occur on the western sides of continents between the latitudes of 30° and 45°. These climates are in the polar front region in winter
column2: and thus have moderate temperatures and changeable
column3: rainy weather. Summers are hot and dry
column4: due to the domination of the subtropical high pressure systems
column5: except in the immediate coastal areas
column6: where summers are milder due to the nearby presence of cold ocean currents that may bring fog but prevent rain.

column1: Ramallah has been described as the seat of power of the Palestinian Authority and serves as the headquarters for most international NGOs and embassies. Hundreds of millions of dollars in aid flowing into the city have boosted Ramallah's economy greatly since the end of the Second Intifada.The Ramallah construction boom is one of the most obvious signs of West Bank economic growth
column2: estimated at an annual rate of 8 percent. This has been attributed to relative stability and Western donor support to the Palestinian Authority. Ramallah's buoyant economy continues to draw Palestinians from other West Bank towns where jobs are fewer. The built-up area has grown fivefold since 2002.By 2010
column3: Ramallah had become the leading center of economic and political activity in the territories under the control of the Palestinian Authority. During a building boom in the early years of the 21st century
column4: apartment buildings and "five-star" hotels were erected
column5: particularly in the Al-Masyoun neighborhood. In 2010
column6: "more than one hundred" Palestinian businesses were reported to have moved to Ramallah from East Jerusalem
column7: because "Here they pay less taxes and have more customers." One local boasted to a journalist that "Ramallah is becoming the de facto capital of Palestine." This boast was seconded by The New York Times which
column9: called Ramallah the "de facto capital of the West Bank. According to Sani Meo
column10: the publisher of This Week in Palestine
column12: Ramallah has done well and Palestine is proud of its achievements." Some Palestinians allege that Ramallah's prosperity is part of an Israeli "conspiracy" to make Ramallah the capital of a Palestinian state

column1: In the aftermath of the 1936–39 Arab revolt
column2: the Ramallah Hospital Foundation was established and registered as a tax exempt organization in New York in 1944. It bought large pieces of land in the south-eastern fringes of the city dedicated for the future hospital. In 1963 a hospital was opened. The present Ramallah Government Hospital and the Palestine Medical Centered are located on the land purchased by the Foundation. In January 1987 the first open-heart surgery was performed at the Hospital under the direction of Dr. Shehadeh (Shawki) Harb
column3: a Palestinian surgeon trained in the United States.

column1: During the annual "Saturday of Light" religious festival (which occurs on the Saturday between Good Friday and Easter Sunday to commemorate the light that tradition holds shone from the tomb of Jesus)
column2: the scouts hold a parade through the city streets to receive the flame from Jerusalem. (The flame is ignited in Jerusalem's Church of the Holy Sepulchre and is passed on through candles and lanterns to regional churches.) A variety of mosques and churches of different denominations dot the landscape.

column14: and the renowned Argentinian-Israeli pianist Daniel Barenboim performs there often. The Khalil Sakakini Cultural Center

column2: like most Palestinian areas
column3: has a rich folklore of song and dance. Songs accompanied people in every occasion whether it was the harvest season
column4: roofing a house
column5: traveling
column6: coming back from travel
column7: engagement
column8: wedding
column9: or even death. Most of the songs were sung by the women with the exception of Zaffeh and Mal'ab which are sung by the men at wedding celebrations. Palestinian educator Bahia Khalil's book "Ramallah Folklore Songs and Traditions" documents to a great extent this oral tradition inherited from one generation to another. The second edition of the book was published in 2002 by the American Federation of Ramallah

column1: Though experts in the field trace the origins of Palestinian costumes to ancient times

column6: and Ayyubids

column2: collector and researcher of Palestinian clothing
column3: sees examples of proto-Palestinian attire in artifacts from the Canaanite period (1500 BCE) such as Egyptian paintings depicting Canaanites in A-shaped garments. Munayyer says that from 1200 BC to 1940 AD
column4: all Palestinian dresses were cut from natural fabrics in a similar A-line shape with triangular sleeves. This shape is known to archaeologists as the "Syrian tunic" and appears in artifacts such as an ivory engraving from Megiddo dating to 1200 BC.Until the 1940s
column5: traditional Palestinian costumes reflected a woman's economic and marital status and her town or district of origin
column6: with knowledgeable observers discerning this information from the fabric
column7: colours
column8: cut
column9: and embroidery motifs (or lack thereof) used in the apparel.Due to the difficulty of travel in the 19th century
column10: villages in Palestine remained isolated. As a result
column11: clothing and accessories became a statement of region. In Ramallah
column12: the back panels of dresses often incorporated a palm tree motif embroidered in cross-stitch. Ramallah women were famous for their distinctive dress of white linen fabric embroidered with red silk thread. The headdress or smadeh worn in Ramallah was common throughout northern Palestine: a small roundish cap
column14: with gold and silver coins set in a fringe with a long veil pinned to the back
